title: Order the Stages of Mitosis
question: Create an interactive diagram game where students arrange the stages of mitosis in correct order: prophase, prometaphase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase, explaining what happens at each stage.

blueprint.title: Mitosis Master: The Cell Division Challenge
blueprint.subject: Biology
blueprint.narrativeIntro: Welcome, aspiring biologist! Your mission is to guide a cell through the intricate dance of mitosis. First, arrange the stages in their correct order, then describe the critical events that unfold in each phase to ensure life's continuity.
blueprint.completionMessage: Congratulations! You've successfully mastered the stages of mitosis, demonstrating a deep understanding of this fundamental biological process. The cell's genetic legacy is secure thanks to your expertise!

config.instruction_text: The cell is preparing for division! Arrange the following stages of mitosis in their correct chronological order, from the initial condensation of chromosomes to the final separation of daughter cells.

feedback.on_correct: Excellent! That stage is in the correct position.
feedback.on_incorrect: Not quite. Consider what happens immediately before or after this stage in the cell cycle.
feedback.on_completion: Fantastic! You've successfully sequenced the five main stages of mitosis. You clearly understand the chronological order of these critical events.

misconceptions.message: Remember, mitosis is a continuous process, even though we divide it into stages for easier understanding. Each stage flows directly into the next.
It's common to confuse cytokinesis with mitosis. While cytokinesis (cytoplasm division) typically overlaps with anaphase and telophase, it's a separate process from nuclear division (mitosis) itself.

Good point to clarify! Chromosomes only adopt their condensed, X-shaped form (sister chromatids) during prophase and metaphase for efficient separation. For most of the cell cycle, they exist as decondensed chromatin.

config.instruction_text: Now that you've ordered the stages, let's delve into the details. Match each description of key events and their functional significance to the correct stage of mitosis shown in the diagram.

feedback.on_correct: Excellent! That description accurately matches the events of this mitotic stage.
feedback.on_incorrect: Not quite. That description belongs to a different stage. Take another look at the key events and their sequence.
feedback.on_completion: Fantastic work! You've successfully described the key events of each mitotic stage, demonstrating a strong understanding of chromosome segregation.

misconceptions.message: Remember, mitosis is a continuous process, not a series of distinct, separate events. We divide it into stages for easier understanding, but the cellular changes flow seamlessly from one to the next.

It's a common point of confusion! Cytokinesis, the division of the cytoplasm, is a separate process that typically overlaps with the later stages of mitosis (anaphase and telophase), but it's not considered one of the mitotic stages itself.

While we often picture chromosomes as X-shaped, they only adopt this condensed form (sister chromatids) during prophase and metaphase of cell division. For most of the cell cycle, they exist as decondensed chromatin within the nucleus.

items.content: Prophase: Chromatin condenses into visible, X-shaped chromosomes. The mitotic spindle begins to form as centrosomes move apart.
items.explanation: This is the first stage. The cell packages its DNA into compact chromosomes to make them easier to move and separate.
items.image_description: A flat educational illustration of a cell with a clearly defined, intact nuclear envelope in cool blue. Inside the nucleus, several distinct, X-shaped chromosomes in a warm orange are scattered. Outside the nucleus, two centrosomes are migrating towards opposite poles, with early mitotic spindle fibers in yellow beginning to radiate from them.

items.content: Prometaphase: The nuclear envelope breaks down. Spindle fibers attach to the kinetochores of the chromosomes.
items.explanation: The nuclear barrier must be removed so the spindle fibers can access and organize the chromosomes for division.
items.image_description: A flat educational illustration of a cell where the nuclear envelope is shown as fragmented, disappearing pieces. The X-shaped orange chromosomes are now in the cytoplasm. Yellow spindle fibers, extending from centrosomes at opposite poles, are actively attaching to the central region (kinetochore) of each chromosome, creating a sense of dynamic movement.

items.content: Metaphase: Chromosomes are aligned in a single file line along the metaphase plate at the cell's equator.
items.explanation: This precise alignment is a critical checkpoint, ensuring that each new cell will receive one copy of every chromosome.
items.image_description: A flat educational illustration of a cell with no nuclear envelope. All the X-shaped orange chromosomes are perfectly aligned in a neat, vertical line down the center of the cell (the metaphase plate). A complete spindle apparatus is visible, with yellow spindle fibers extending from centrosomes at each pole and attached to every chromosome.

items.content: Anaphase: Sister chromatids separate and are pulled towards opposite poles by shortening spindle fibers.
items.explanation: This is the stage where the duplicated genetic material is physically separated, ensuring each daughter cell gets an identical set.
items.image_description: A flat educational illustration of a cell that is visibly elongating. The sister chromatids have separated, and now individual, V-shaped chromosomes in orange are being pulled towards opposite poles of the cell by shortening yellow spindle fibers. There is a clear space forming in the middle of the cell between the two separating groups of chromosomes.

items.content: Telophase: Chromosomes arrive at the poles, decondense, and new nuclear envelopes form around the two sets. Cytokinesis begins.
items.explanation: This final stage concludes mitosis by re-forming two nuclei and marks the beginning of the cytoplasm division to create two separate cells.
items.image_description: A flat educational illustration of a cell with a cleavage furrow pinching inward, indicating the start of cytokinesis. At each pole, a new nuclear envelope is forming around a cluster of chromosomes, which are decondensing and becoming less distinct (more like tangled orange chromatin). The spindle fibers are disassembling and are mostly gone.
